He noticed it every time he walked around the room. Now he picked it up and looked at it. It was the New Testament in Russian. The cover was old and worn.

“Where did you get that?” he called to her from across the room. 

She was still standing in the same spot, three steps from the table. 

“It was brought to me,” she answered, almost unwillingly, without looking at him. 

“Who brought it?” 

“Lizaveta, I asked her for it.” 

“Lizaveta! That’s strange!” he thought. 

Everything about Sonia seemed stranger and more amazing to him every moment. He took the book to the candle and started flipping through the pages. 

“Where is the story of Lazarus?” he suddenly asked. 

Sonia looked stubbornly at the ground and didn’t answer. She was standing sideways to the table. 

“Where is the raising of Lazarus? Find it for me, Sonia.” 

She glanced at him. 

“You're not looking in the right place... It’s in the fourth gospel,” she whispered firmly, without looking at him. 

“Find it and read it to me,” he said. He sat down with his elbow on the table, rested his head on his hand, and looked away, ready to listen. 

“In three weeks, they’ll welcome me in the mad-house! I’ll be there if I’m not in a worse place,” he muttered to himself.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov questions Sonia about her faith and the New Testament, revealing his growing curiosity and confusion about her beliefs.
